articles.author: Adam Rackis
articles.description:
So, you‚Äôve decided to build a blog with Next.js. Like any dev blogger, you‚Äôd like to have code snippets in your posts that are formatted nicely with syntax highlighting. Perhaps you also want to display line numbers in the ‚Ä¶
Syntax Highlighting (and More!) With Prism on a Static Site originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Syntax Highlighting (and More!) With Prism on a Static Site

articles.author: Nick Sypteras
articles.description:
If you‚Äôve spent time looking at open-source repos on¬†GitHub, you‚Äôve probably noticed that most of them use badges in their README files.¬†Take the official React repository,¬†for instance.¬†There are GitHub badges all over the¬†README¬†file that¬†communicate important dynamic info,¬†like the latest released ‚Ä¶
Adding Custom GitHub Badges to Your Repo originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Adding Custom GitHub Badges to Your Repo

articles.author: Preethi
articles.description:
In design, reflections are stylized mirror images of objects. Even though they are not as popular as shadows, they have their moments ‚Äî just think about the first time you explored the different font formats in MS Word or PowerPoint: ‚Ä¶
Creating Realistic Reflections With CSS originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Creating Realistic Reflections With CSS

articles.author: Jhey Tompkins
articles.description:
Howdy y‚Äôall! Unless you‚Äôve been living under a rock (and maybe even then), you‚Äôve undoubtedly heard the news that CSS-Tricks, was acquired by DigitalOcean. Congratulations to everyone! ü•≥
As a little hurrah to commemorate the occasion, I wanted to ‚Ä¶
Creating the DigitalOcean Logo in 3D With CSS originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Creating the DigitalOcean Logo in 3D With CSS

articles.author: Adam Rackis
articles.description:
In my last article, we went over how to set up a web app that serves chunks and bundles of CSS and JavaScript from CloudFront. We integrated it into Vite so that when the app runs in a browser, ‚Ä¶
Setting Up CloudFront to Host Your Web App originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Setting Up CloudFront to Host Your Web App

articles.author: Temani Afif
articles.description:
A while ago, Geoff wrote an article about a cool hover effect. The effect relies on a combination of CSS pseudo-elements, transforms, and transitions. A lot of comments have shown that the same effect can be done using background ‚Ä¶
Cool Hover Effects That Use Background Properties originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Cool Hover Effects That Use Background Properties

articles.author: Dan Christofi
articles.description:
When creating a component-based, front-end infrastructure, one of the biggest pain points I‚Äôve personally encountered is making components that are both reusable and responsive when there are nested components within components.
Take the following ‚Äúcall to action‚Äù (<CTA />‚Ä¶
Avoiding the Pitfalls of Nested Components in a Design System originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Avoiding the Pitfalls of Nested Components in a Design System

articles.author: Mark Noonan
articles.description:
Automated front-end tests are awesome. We can write a test with code to visit a page ‚Äî or load up just a single component ‚Äî and have that test code click on things or type text like a user would, ‚Ä¶
Writing Strong Front-end Test Element Locators originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Writing Strong Front-end Test Element Locators

articles.author: Greg Sullivan
articles.description:
In the 15 or so years since I started making WordPress websites, nothing has had more of an impact on my productivity ‚Äî and my ability to enjoy front-end development ‚Äî than adding Tailwind CSS to my workflow (and it ‚Ä¶
Adding Tailwind CSS to New and Existing WordPress Themes originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Adding Tailwind CSS to New and Existing WordPress Themes

articles.author: Paul Esch-Laurent
articles.description:
Mermaid diagrams and flowcharts have been gaining traction, especially with GitHub‚Äôs announcement that they are natively supported in Markdown. Let‚Äôs take a look at what they are, how to use them, and just as importantly: why.
Just like you ‚Ä¶
Making Mermaid Diagrams in Markdown originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Making Mermaid Diagrams in Markdown

articles.author: Shimin Zhang
articles.description:
I‚Äôm a big fan of movies by J.J. Abrams. I enjoy their tight plots, quippy dialog, and of course: anamorphic lens flares. Filmmakers like Abrams use lens flare to add a dash of ‚Äòhomemade‚Äô realism to their movies, ‚Ä¶
Add a CSS Lens Flare to Photos for a Bright Touch originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Add a CSS Lens Flare to Photos for a Bright Touch

sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine ‚Äî For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: How difficult can it be to design a bulletproof language selector? It‚Äôs not as straightforward as one might think. We need to avoid redirects, decouple our language and country presets, allow for overrides, and use non-modal windows. Let‚Äôs dive in!
articles.title: Designing A Better Language Selector

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Josh Comeau)
articles.description: Developers often reach for UI frameworks like Bootstrap or Material UI, hoping that they‚Äôll save a bunch of time and quickly build a professional-looking app. Unfortunately, things rarely work out this way. Let‚Äôs talk about it.
articles.title: You Don‚Äôt Need A UI Framework

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Let‚Äôs welcome May with a new collection of wallpapers. Designed with love by artists and designers from across the globe, they come in versions with and without a calendar for May 2022.
articles.title: Make A Wish (May 2022 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Steve Sewell)
articles.description: Introducing Partytown, a lightweight open-source solution that reduces execution delays due to third-party JavaScript by offloading third-party scripts to web workers, which run in background threads.
articles.title: How Partytown Eliminates Website Bloat From Third-Party Scripts

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Nathan Smith)
articles.description: In this article, Nathan Smith explains how to create modal dialog windows with rich interaction that will only require authoring HTML in order to be used. They are based on Web Components that are currently supported by every major browser.
articles.title: CTA Modal: How To Build A Web Component

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: We should be able to measure how well a particular design solves a particular problem. Let‚Äôs explore design KPIs that capture user‚Äôs experience, how to measure them and how to keep both users and business stakeholders happy, over time.
articles.title: Boosting UX With Design KPIs

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ceara Crawshaw)
articles.description: When bad UX has lingered in a product for so long, it can feel like a mountain to overcome. In this article, Ceara Crawshaw shares her advice on how you can invoke joy and assure the quality in the work done on product teams.
articles.title: Preventing Bad UX Through Integrated Design Workflows

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Jhey Tompkins)
articles.description: In this article, Jhey Tompkins explores one of GreenSocks‚Äô newest plugins alongside React to create an impractical whimsical spin on a well-known native element: ``.
articles.title: What If Our Sliders Actually Slid?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Georgy Marchuk)
articles.description: Have you ever wondered, why do people write CLI tools? When is a good time to think about yours? Today we‚Äôll touch on these questions, along with some tips to remember when creating one. However, all of this serves as a prelude to the real topic: end-to-end testing of CLI tools.
articles.title: Testing The CLI The Way People Use It

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: In UX, we can use navigation queries, evaluation journeys, A-Z index and tap-ahead autocomplete to help users get where they want to be, faster. Let‚Äôs find out how.
articles.title: Designing Better Navigation With Navigation Queries

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Who doesn‚Äôt love a good timesaver? In this post, we compiled useful productivity tips and tools that help you speed up routine tasks, enhance your development workflow, and stay organized.
articles.title: Productivity Tips And Tools For A More Efficient Workflow

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ekene Eze)
articles.description: In this article, Ekene Eze shares his thoughts about the direction of the web in 2022, and what solutions we can expect to see come up in the ecosystem to significantly improve the Jamstack experience.
articles.title: Jamstack Rendering Patterns: The Evolution

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Lee Munroe)
articles.description: What are the benefits of using push notifications and what can you use them for? In this article, Lee Munroe explains how to implement them and which practices are best to follow.
articles.title: The Ultimate Guide To Push Notifications For Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Marli Mesibov)
articles.description: Storytelling is a powerful tool for any UX designer. It helps create a product and understand the people who use it. In this article, Marli Mesibov takes a real-life example of an app she helped to build in 2017 and explains five steps you can use to help you build a story into your user experience.
articles.title: How To Use Storytelling In UX

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Boag)
articles.description: Whether you work in-house or run a digital agency, there are occasions when you will consider hiring freelancers to supplement your team. Today, we‚Äôll take a look into a platform known as [Upwork](https://upwork.pxf.io/c/1221738/1245573/13634) and the best ways in finding the the right freelancers as well as integrating them into your team.
articles.title: When And How To Use Freelancers In Your Organization

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Carousels don‚Äôt have a good reputation, and rightfully so. But we can make them more useful. **Best practices and guidelines** to improve the carousel design with honest scrolling direction, labels, thumbnails and grouped prev/next-buttons.
articles.title: Designing A Better Carousel UX

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Dan Donald)
articles.description: Like many things, a design system isn‚Äôt ever a finished thing ‚Äî it‚Äôs a journey. How we go about that journey can affect the things we produce along the way. Before diving in and starting to plan anything out, be clear about where the benefits and the risks might lie.
articles.title: Around The Artifacts Of Design Systems (Case Study)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: This new attribute will enable us to fine-tune relative resource priority, improve LCP performance, deprioritize JavaScript fetch calls, and much more. Let‚Äôs check out fetchpriority and explore some potential use cases.
articles.title: Boost Resource Loading With fetchpriority, A New Priority Hint

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Caleb Olojo)
articles.description: Data is among the most important things that make up a web application or a conventional native app. We need data to be able to see and perhaps understand the purpose of an application. In this article, we‚Äôll look at another approach to obtaining data in an application that requires authentication or authorization using Next.js.
articles.title: Dynamic Data-Fetching In An Authenticated Next.js App

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: In this series of articles, we highlight design patterns and techniques to design better interfaces. You can also find more examples in [‚ÄúSmart Interface Design Patterns‚Äù](https://smart-interface-design-patterns.com/), a 6h-video course with 100s of hand-picked examples, curated by Vitaly.
articles.title: Designing Better Breadcrumbs

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: [Devs For Ukraine](https://www.devsforukraine.io/) is a free online charity conference organized by the lovely people at Remote. Two days filled with talks from engineering leaders around the globe, in support of Ukraine. April 25‚Äì26.
articles.title: Devs For Ukraine, A Free Online Charity Conference üá∫üá¶

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Boag)
articles.description: Whether you work in-house or for an external agency, we all share one challenge ‚Äî dealing with stakeholders, be they your boss, colleagues, or clients. In this post, veteran web designer Paul Boag shares his approach to getting things done in even the most challenging organizations.
articles.title: How To Get Work Done: Wrangling Stakeholders And Overcoming Obstacles
